whisper.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to speak or say something very quietly, using your breath rather than your voice
whisper.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: You don’t have to whisper, no one can hear us.
‘I’ve missed you, ’ he whispered in her ear.
What are you two whispering about over there?
James leaned over to whisper something to Michael.
whisper.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to say or suggest something privately or secretly
whisper.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Staff were whispering that the company was about to go out of business.
whisper.translation[1].definitions[0].de: a very quiet voice you make using your breath and no sound
whisper.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: ‘Where are we going?’ he asked in a whisper.
whisper.translation[1].definitions[1].de: a piece of news or information that has not been officially announced and may or may not be true
whisper.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The first whisper of the redundancies came from the newspapers.
There are whispers that the actor was seen checking into a hospital last week.
whisper.translation[1].note_box[0].secti: a hoarse whisper
Her voice came out as a hoarse whisper.
a loud whisper
‘Where are you going?’ I said in a loud whisper.
a low/soft whisper
When he spoke, it was in a low whisper.
a stage whisper
'What’s going on?' Rory said, in a stage whisper.
a hushed whisper
They spoke in the hushed whispers of churchgoers.
an urgent whisper
‘Daddy!’ he said in an urgent whisper.
a fierce whisper
‘Let me go!’ she said in a fierce whisper.
a conspiratorial whisper
‘Does she suspect anything?’ said Ruth in a conspiratorial whisper.
speak/talk in whispers
They spoke in quick, urgent whispers.
barely/hardly/scarcely above a whisper
'Not me', he said, in a voice barely above a whisper.
